intro: Caralluma nebrownii, commonly known as the Indian date cactus, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of India and Pakistan. It belongs to the family Nyctaginaceae and is characterized by its succulent, spineless stems that store water, enabling it to survive in dry environments. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom during the warmer months, typically from April to June. Its leaves are reduced to small spines, and it has a shallow root system adapted to absorb moisture from the soil. Caralluma nebrownii is often cultivated as an ornamental plant due to its unique appearance and low maintenance requirements.
